desc.size: Tree, 15 - 24 m tall, trunk diameter 45 - 90 cm. Crown uniformly pyramidal.

part.partText: pinkish gray to almost black, thick, becoming coarse with age. Older trunks deeply fissured and flaking.
stiff, smooth, yellowish brown to olive-brown, becoming darker with age.
reddish brown, 1.2 - 2 cm long, cylindrical, slightly pointed, with a white resin coating.
in clusters of two, dark green, 8 - 16 cm long, incurved, sharp-pointed, thin and flexible (won't snap apart when bent).
yellow, about 2 cm long, cylindrical, clustered at the base of new shoots.

part.partName: woody, stalkless, upright, lustrous yellow-brown, 5 - 8 cm long, egg-shaped; scales smooth with a deciduous prickle on the thickened apex. Seeds reddish brown, 6 mm long, with wings 1.5 - 2 cm long.
part.partText: red, small, cylindrical, at tips of new shoots. Pollination between cones occurs in May and June.

similarSpecies.comments: Pinus nigra is best identified by its pinkish gray bark, large resin-coated terminal buds, long, stiff needles in clusters of two (which won’t snap apart when bent), and yellowish brown, egg-shaped seed cones. It’s distinguished from P. resinosa by having needles that won’t snap apart when bent and yellowish brown seed cones with a prickle.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Normally occurs in mesic woods and upland dunes, but does not occur naturally in the Chicago Region. The population at Illinois Beach State Park in Lake County, Illinois, was planted in the 1860's in an effort to stabilize the dunes.

notes.comments: Introduced from Europe. Commonly used for landscape and shade purposes, being hardy and easily transplanted when small. Often planted along highways for its tolerance of air pollution, salt spray, and dry soils. There are many geographic varieties. Diplodia needle-cast disease is common.

etymology.comments: Pinus is the Latin word for pine. Nigra means black.
